line=9546 tag=L+SY:               Chelswu-ka [ ei kocangna-n]REL khempwuthei- lul kochi-ess-ta

line=9551 tag=B:
line=9552 tag=L+CN:               Chelswu-ka [khempwuthei-ka kocangna-n]REL kesi-ul kochi-ess-ta

doc_id=1274 igt_id=igt1274-542 9555 9570 M+AC+CN B L+CN G B B M B M M M M M M M T
language: Korean (kor)
line=9555 tag=M+AC+CN:  (5.2)     a. Externally Headed Relative Clause (EHRC)                   (Jhang 1991)
line=9556 tag=B:
line=9557 tag=L+CN:               [totwuk-i      ei hwumchi-n]REL       poseki-i    kacca-ta
line=9558 tag=G:                thief-NOM         steal -COMP         jewelry-NOM fake-DEC
line=9559 tag=B:
line=9560 tag=B:
line=9561 tag=M:  158   Some part of this chapter is presented in B.S. Yang (1993a, b).
line=9562 tag=B:
line=9563 tag=M:  159See Kuroda (1976), Itô (1986), Ishii (1989), Ohara (1994), Dryer (1994a), and Hirose
line=9564 tag=M:  and Ohori (1992), among others for Japanese. Ohara (1994) argues that the relative
line=9565 tag=M:  clauses analyzed as IHRCs in Japanese are not IHRCs, but "pseudo-relatives". Dryer
line=9566 tag=M:  (1994a) argues against the argument of Ohara (1994) claiming that they are indeed
line=9567 tag=M:  IHRCs. Horie (1993) studies the different acceptability of IHRCs in Japanese and Korean
line=9568 tag=M:  to the lexico-semantic differences between Japanese no and Korean kes.
line=9569 tag=M:
line=9570 tag=T:                 "The jewelry that the thief stole is fake."

doc_id=1274 igt_id=igt1274-543 9572 9575 M+CN B L+SY G
language: Korean (kor)
line=9572 tag=M+CN:          b. Internally Headed Relative Clause (IHRC)
line=9573 tag=B:
line=9574 tag=L+SY:           [totwuk-i  poseki -ul hwumchi-n ] REL               kesi-i   kacca-ta
line=9575 tag=G:            thief-NOM jewelry-ACC steal- COMP                    one -NOM fake-DEC

language: Korean (kor)

line=9580 tag=G:                          fresh -RETOR-COMP           fish-NOM rotten-PST-DEC

line=703 tag=L+CR+SY:         Jinho-nun       [[ e       tomangka-n]-un        totwuki]-ul   capassta.
line=704 tag=L+CR+SY:                                i

doc_id=1775 igt_id=igt1775-7 984 999 L+SY B G+SY B L B G B T M B T+AL B T+AL B T+AL
language: Korean (kor)
line=984 tag=L+SY:  (7)    Jinho-nun       [[koyangi-ka cwi-lul           coch-ko        iss-n]-un
line=985 tag=B:
line=986 tag=G+SY:         J.-top          [[cat-nom       mouse-acc      chase-comp     cop-imprf]-rel
line=987 tag=B:
line=988 tag=L:         kes]-ul         capessta.
line=989 tag=B:
line=990 tag=G:         kes]-acc        caught.
line=991 tag=B:
line=992 tag=T:                         `A/the cat was chasing a/the mouse and Jinho caught the cat.'
line=993 tag=M:         Reading 1:
line=994 tag=B:

doc_id=1817 igt_id=igt1817-1 105 108 M+LN+CN L G T
language: Korean (kor)
line=105 tag=M+LN+CN:  Korean (data from O'Grady 2001:62)
line=106 tag=L:      Nay-ka     John-ul i                 kes-ul    cwu-ess-ta
line=107 tag=G:      I-Nom      John-Acc this             thing-Acc give-Pst-Decl
line=108 tag=T:      `I gave John this.'

doc_id=1817 igt_id=igt1817-2 110 123 L G B B M M M M M M M M M T
language: Korean (kor)
line=110 tag=L:      *Nay-ka       John-ul i              kes-ul    malhay-ss-ta
line=111 tag=G:      I-Nom         John-Acc this          thing-Acc tell-Pst-Decl
line=112 tag=B:
line=113 tag=B:
line=114 tag=M:      1
line=115 tag=M:         The double-object and dative constructions are often referred to as the after-verb structure and the after-
line=116 tag=M:  preposition structure; these terms specify the position of the IO in each of the two constructions (Yule 1998). Many
line=117 tag=M:  people also refer to the DOC as the ditransitive structure to indicate the number of object arguments the verb takes.
line=118 tag=M:
line=119 tag=M:                                                                                                 2
line=120 tag=M:           Working Papers in Linguistics--University of Hawai`i at Mnoa, Vol. 34(4) (2003)
line=121 tag=M:
line=122 tag=M:                           2
line=123 tag=T:     `I told John this.'

doc_id=2018 igt_id=igt2018-5 76 85 M+AC+LN L+CR L+CR G+CR G+CR B L+CR L+CR G T
language: Korean (kor)
line=76 tag=M+AC+LN:  (5)    Korean (Sohn 1999: 308)
line=77 tag=L+CR:                    ka-to
line=78 tag=L+CR:         nay ka
line=79 tag=G+CR:         I          go-though(=      CONV)
line=80 tag=G+CR:              NOM
line=81 tag=B:
line=82 tag=L+CR:                             ka-n-ta.
line=83 tag=L+CR:         nami nun an
line=84 tag=G:         Nami TOP NEG go-INDIC-DEC             L
line=85 tag=T:         `Even though I go, Nami will not.'

doc_id=2330 igt_id=igt2330-29 765 775 L G T M M M M M M M L+AL
language: Korean (kor)
line=765 tag=L:          i. * casin-i John-ul kewul-ey pichwue poassta
line=766 tag=G:               self-NOM John-ACC mirror re ect
line=767 tag=T:             `Himself saw John in the mirror'
line=768 tag=M:  On our account, this example is ungrammatical for two reasons. First, the re exiveis unbound yielding a principle
line=769 tag=M:  A violation. Additionally, the R-expression John is -marked and hence bound by the sub ject re exive, yielding a
line=770 tag=M:  principle C violation. On the accountgiven in the text, scrambling the R-expression past the sub ject will eliminate
line=771 tag=M:  only one of these binding violations, namely that of principle A. The R-expression will have been -marked at D-
line=772 tag=M:  Structure since it is bound by a sub ject, and hence will continue to be bound at all levels of representation, yielding
line=773 tag=M:  the principle C violation. However, such scrambling results in grammaticality as shown in (ii). The slight marginal
line=774 tag=M:  status is due only to the awkwardness of this construction.
line=775 tag=L+AL:          ii. ? John-uli casin-i ti kewul-ey pichwue poassta

doc_id=3857 igt_id=igt3857-36 630 633 M+EX L G T
language: Korean (kor)
line=630 tag=M+EX:  (25) Relative clauses   headed by a universal quantifier:
line=631 tag=L:       amwu-rato/-na       chayyongha-n hoysa-nun       motwu ssuleci-ess-ta.

line=633 tag=T:       'Every company     that hired any number of/just any employee collapsed.'

doc_id=3859 igt_id=igt3859-1 56 60 M+EX L+AC G T T+DB
language: Korean (kor)
line=56 tag=M+EX:  Stage 3. It seems... (inference): Based on objective judgment
line=57 tag=L+AC:  (3) kulno tewuk syelwehAosinAnka siputa hAni (kyeychwuk ilki 17th C, 1:14b)
line=58 tag=G:  Thatwith more sorrowfulHONPRESQ sipuEND sayCONN
line=59 tag=T:  "He said (to the King) that the Queen seemed more sorrowful because of that (the failed plan to make her
line=60 tag=T+DB:  son King)" > the Queen is probably more sorrowful because of that.

doc_id=3859 igt_id=igt3859-2 62 66 M+LN+EX L G L+AC T
language: Korean (kor)
line=62 tag=M+LN+EX:  Stage 4. Probably...         => in Modern Korean replaced by ­tus siph
line=63 tag=L:  (4) nAyilun chenki tyohAlka siputa yekuy salAmto niluoni coco chwulsenhAApsai
